comment:
This position is known as the Center Counter, or Scandinavian defense. While
objectively sound for black, I don't recommend it as this early queen sortie,
as it doesn't help black's central control much, plus black always has to be
careful where he moves his queen again, as the monarch is always pushed around
by White with an eventual Nc3 or c4. If black isn't careful, he could lose his
queen easily, as this game demonstrates.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6
comment:
A good move by black. He
gets his knight out, while at the same time puts pressure on White by
threatening to capture on d4.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6
comment:
Natural, but inaccurate. An
aggressive ...Bg4! followed by castling queenside could really put the
pressure on White's center. For example, if ...Bg4 5. c4?? Qe4+ 6. Be2 Bxf3 7.
gxf3 Qxd4 leaves black up a pawn! This is one reason why it's common for white
to boot black's queen from the center as soon as possible by playing Nc3 move
2. As it stands, white gets a free hand to push black around.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+
comment:
? This only forces white to develop his bishop with a gain of time. Black has
to accept the fact his only reasonable posts for her is d6 or d8.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+ 6. Bd2 Qb6 7. c5
comment:
?? The key blunder. Like it or not, black had to play 7. ... Qf5. After
this, White has a won game, and you played well to convert it.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+ 6. Bd2 Qb6 7. c5 Qxb2 8. Bc3 Qxa1 9. Bxa1 Bg4 10. Be2
comment:
A little passive, but of course a reasonable move.
Instead Bb5, followed by Nbd2, Qa4 would really put the pressure on black.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+ 6. Bd2 Qb6 7. c5 Qxb2 8. Bc3 Qxa1 9. Bxa1 Bg4 10. Be2 e6 11. h3 Bf5 12. Bb5 Rb8 13. O-O
comment:
Again, sound, but Nbd2, followed by Bxc6, and
Qa4 and/or Ne5 would make black resign soon.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+ 6. Bd2 Qb6 7. c5 Qxb2 8. Bc3 Qxa1 9. Bxa1 Bg4 10. Be2 e6 11. h3 Bf5 12. Bb5 Rb8 13. O-O a6 14. Ba4 Be7 15. Re1 O-O 16. Bc2
comment:
Why not 16. Nbd2? Then Bxc6 and Qa4 would pick up some of black's pawns
for sure. There are many ways to win at this point.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+ 6. Bd2 Qb6 7. c5 Qxb2 8. Bc3 Qxa1 9. Bxa1 Bg4 10. Be2 e6 11. h3 Bf5 12. Bb5 Rb8 13. O-O a6 14. Ba4 Be7 15. Re1 O-O 16. Bc2 Bxc2 17. Qxc2 h6 18. Ne5
comment:
Good. When up material (such as a Queen for a rook in your case), trade pieces.
This makes the your material advantage more effective.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+ 6. Bd2 Qb6 7. c5 Qxb2 8. Bc3 Qxa1 9. Bxa1 Bg4 10. Be2 e6 11. h3 Bf5 12. Bb5 Rb8 13. O-O a6 14. Ba4 Be7 15. Re1 O-O 16. Bc2 Bxc2 17. Qxc2 h6 18. Ne5 Nb4 19. Qc4 Nbd5 20. Nc3 Rfd8 21. Ne4 c6 22. Nxf6+ Nxf6 23. Ng6
comment:
This is okay, but if black replied
23. ... Bf8! 24. Nxf8 Kxf8, with the idea of not moving his pawns and
establishing a blockade, it would make it more difficult for white to win.
With the text, black opens lines in White's favor.

moves: 1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. d4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Nf6 5. c4 Qa5+ 6. Bd2 Qb6 7. c5 Qxb2 8. Bc3 Qxa1 9. Bxa1 Bg4 10. Be2 e6 11. h3 Bf5 12. Bb5 Rb8 13. O-O a6 14. Ba4 Be7 15. Re1 O-O 16. Bc2 Bxc2 17. Qxc2 h6 18. Ne5 Nb4 19. Qc4 Nbd5 20. Nc3 Rfd8 21. Ne4 c6 22. Nxf6+ Nxf6 23. Ng6 Bxc5
